Dialogue.NPCText:
The smith before you is thickset, his skin mottled by old burns and fresh scars. His hammer hand flexes restlessly, and his steely gaze flickers with suspicion.

“What brings you to my forge? Looking to have something mended, or hoping I’ll hand out miracles to strangers? Speak up. The city’s full of cowards and spies these days—best you prove you’re not one of them.”

Option.text: I heard you forge weapons like no other.
Who are you, really?
I was told you have a job for those worthy.
You seem like you've seen your share of war...
I’m only passing through.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn snorts, spitting into the ashes.
“If you’re after fancy baubles, find a Conclave pet. I don’t make trinkets for parade mages. I make steel that bites and armor that remembers every scar. Once, I was Warden of the Outer Rim. Held the north quarter when Minax first sent her devils on winged things—lost most of my lads, and nearly the city itself.
Now I shape iron for those I judge worthy. Prove yourself, and you might earn more than the city’s empty praise.”

Option.text: How could I prove myself to you?
Why do you hate the Conclave so much?
Tell me more about Minax’s attack.
I’ll be going, then.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Dorn Makel. Ex-warden, former captain, now Aerilon’s half-tamed ghost. Most of the Conclave would rather I disappear. Selara? Hides behind her spells. Corvus Deyne—wants the city bristling like a hedgehog. The rest, they mutter about the ‘old guard.’
I answer to no one now, and I owe no favors. Unless you’re here to prove otherwise.”

Option.text: What happened during the Outer Rim siege?
Why are you so distrustful?
Do you have any work for someone persistent?
I’ll leave you to your forge.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn looks you over, eyes narrowed.
“Work, is it? You want a weapon worthy of tearing through Minax’s rifts, you’ll have to do more than fetch coals. I don’t trust mages, and I trust this city’s politics even less. But sometimes... even an old blade needs a steady hand behind it.

There’s a supplier outside the city—goes by ‘the Rotworm Enthusiast.’ Strange sort, obsessed with the big burrowers. He handles a fungus used for my hardening acid, but lately, even he’s spooked by Minax’s shadows. I need a shipment delivered—quiet, careful, no Conclave spies trailing you.

Do this right, and maybe I’ll see the measure of you. You up for it?”

Option.text: I’ll do it. Give me the package for the Rotworm Enthusiast.
Who is this Rotworm Enthusiast?
Why such secrecy? What’s so dangerous about fungus?
What makes you distrust the Conclave so much?
Maybe I’m not suited to this.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn hands you a sturdy, oilskin-wrapped bundle. The scent of earth and iron clings to it.

“Deliver that to the Rotworm Enthusiast outside the city. He’ll know what to do. Don’t let any bright-robed Conclave whelp catch you; this is between smiths and survivors. When it’s done, come back, and maybe I’ll trust you with a real commission. Earn Aerilon’s respect, and maybe—just maybe—you’ll have mine.”

Option.text: I’ll return when the job is done.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn actually cracks a crooked smile.
“You won’t mistake him. Man’s got more fungus in his beard than I’ve got scars. Obsessed with rotworms—keeps one as a pet, or so he claims. Knows more about the guts of the earth than half the miners in Minoc. Don’t ask him about his ‘children’ unless you’ve got half a day to waste.
Still, he’s never failed me. If you need to know more, ask him yourself.”

Option.text: Right, I’ll deliver the package.
I’m having second thoughts.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“You ever try forging steel in a city made of floating rock? The levitation crystals leak strange energies—normal flux eats right through plate in a year. The Rotworm Enthusiast’s fungus, ground just so, makes an acid that tempers metal against the city’s magic. Without it, even my best blades would warp and shatter the first time a Conclave apprentice swings them.
The Conclave claims to protect us, but they don’t understand the grit needed to keep this city from falling apart. Some of us trust what’s grown in dirt and blood, not in fancy spellbooks.”

Option.text: I’ll deliver the package as you asked.
Sounds risky. Maybe another time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn’s voice is low, almost a growl.
“You ever watch the Conclave argue about how many spells to cast while your squad dies screaming? They’re powerful, sure, but they don’t bleed for this city. I lost friends holding the Outer Rim, and all the archmages did was count casualties and close another gate.
If they want my steel, they can come earn it. You—well, you’ve got a chance to show you’re not like them.”

Option.text: Let me prove myself on this errand.
Maybe another time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn stares into the forge, lost in memory.
“Minax’s skybeasts tore the Outer Rim apart—never seen so much blood in the clouds. Most of my men gone in minutes. Conclave tried, but magic fizzled in the storm. After that, I traded the warden’s helm for a smith’s hammer. I forge for the defenders now—the real ones.
If Minax comes again, I aim to be ready. You want to help? Start by delivering that package. No glory, just work.”

Option.text: I’ll do it. Hand over the package.
That’s not a fight I want any part of.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Trust is earned on the anvil, not in a handshake. I’ve seen too many traitors—some wore Conclave robes, some wore my own badge. Deliver this for me, clean and quiet, and we’ll talk trust. Otherwise, you’re just another name in a city that’s already forgotten too many.”

Option.text: Give me the package. I’ll deliver it.
Trust goes both ways, smith. Farewell.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn shrugs, turning back to his work.
“Suit yourself. But don’t come asking for favors until you’ve proven you’re worth a damn. Aerilon’s got enough talkers—what it needs are doers.”

Option.text: Maybe I’ll return when I’m ready to prove myself.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn exhales through his nose, the sound more sigh than breath.
“That obvious, eh? These burns don’t come from cooking stew. I’ve seen skyships fall in flames. I’ve heard the screams of men twisted by Minax’s rift spawn. And I’ve buried more comrades than names I care to remember.

Still… you're not the first to ask. Maybe you're worth a story or two.”

Option.text: Tell me about the Outer Rim and what happened there.
What drives you now, Dorn?
Do you miss being a Warden?
You seem to hold onto memories. Any you care to share?
Never mind. I didn’t mean to pry.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn’s eyes cloud over.
“The Rim was where Aerilon touched the edge of the world. First line of defense. When Minax’s skyspawn hit us, we weren’t ready. The bastards didn’t fly straight. They *twisted* space. One moment the walls were there, the next they weren’t.

My hammer arm hasn't been the same since that night. Not from the fight—*from dragging bodies out of burning crystal bunkers.*”

Option.text: That sounds like a heavy burden.
And the Conclave did nothing?
What kind of enemies did Minax send?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Burden? Nah. It's duty. The weight only crushes you when you forget why you carry it.”

Dorn reaches into a pouch and tosses you a sliver of blackened metal.

Option.text: Thank you. I’ll remember this.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn grits his teeth.
“Selara did what she could. Corvus... he just watched. Said it was a 'test of readiness.' I stopped following orders that day. The Conclave's too busy measuring arcane pulses to see when men are dying on the ground.”

Option.text: That explains your distrust.

Dialogue.NPCText: “We called them 'Riftborn'. They weren't natural. They moved like fish in water—but through air, stone, even thoughts. Some of my men started screaming about their mothers being alive in the sky. Others just melted. Minax doesn't invade like a general—she *rewrites the battlefield* itself.”

Option.text: And you survived all that?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn hammers down on a glowing bar of metal with sudden force.
“Still breathing, aren’t I? I’ve got a forge, scars, and a few regrets. That’s more than most. And now I make weapons for those who might write a better ending than I got.”

He glances at you sideways.
“You keep asking questions like these, I might start thinking you actually give a damn.”

Option.text: What drives you now?
What do you miss about being a Warden?
Tell me about those you lost.
I’d like to earn your respect.
You’ve given me much to think on.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“What drives me? Making sure my blades outlive my bones. That someone holds them who won’t flinch when the skies rip open again.

I’ve got nightmares, sure—but nightmares sharpen better steel than daydreams ever will.”

Option.text: That’s damn poetic.
So you still believe Aerilon can be defended?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn grunts.
“Don’t go spreading that around. I’ve got a reputation for grumbling, not reciting bard tales.”

Option.text: Your secret’s safe. For now.
Let’s talk about something else.

Dialogue.NPCText: “With the right people, maybe. But not if it stays ruled by backroom schemers. That’s why I test who I work for. You want my steel? Earn my trust. Simple as that.”

Option.text: Then I’ll do that. I want to prove myself.
Trust is earned both ways, Dorn.
Option.action: SendMessage:You feel Dorn watching you more closely now.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn looks away, silent for a long beat.
“I miss my men. I miss knowing the guard rotation without glancing at a damn clock. I miss knowing *who* I was.

But we don’t get to keep the old world when the sky shatters, do we?”

Option.text: What would you do if you could go back?

Dialogue.NPCText: “I’d still take the forge, in the end. But I’d make sure every recruit had armor fit to hold *against Minax*, not just pretty plating for parade day.”

Option.text: You still protect people, Dorn. Just differently.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn nods, just once.
“Hah. Maybe you’re not just another idle wanderer.”

Option.text: I’ll take that as a compliment.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn walks over to a small wooden box tucked near the forge.
“I keep their insignias. Each one a reason I keep hammering steel. Maybe someday, they’ll be remembered for more than the street names.”

He opens the box and holds out a small, charred insignia pin.

Option.text: May I keep it?
Let them rest. I won’t disturb that memory.

Dialogue.NPCText: “You’ve got the heart. Take it. But wear it proud—or not at all.”

Option.text: Thank you, Dorn. I won’t forget them.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Dorn nods, slowly.
“That’s the answer I was hoping for.”

Option.text: Farewell, Warden.
